class mfm.fluorescence.fps.dynamic.Sticking(structure, quenching_parameter=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: mfm.parameter.AggregatedParameters

slow_center¶

The location of the slow part of the accessible volume.

slow_fact¶

Slowing factor of the dye close to a slow-center. The diffusion coefficient is multiplied by this value.

slow_radius¶

The radius around the C-alpha atoms which is considered as slow part of the accessible volume

sticky_mode¶

If this value is set to quencher only the quencher slow down the dye if it is surface the C-beta atoms of all amino-acids slow down the dye. If the quencher mode is used the quenching_parameter parameter has to be passed upon initialization of the class.

class mfm.fluorescence.fps.dynamic.StickingWidget(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: mfm.fluorescence.fps.dynamic.Sticking, PyQt4.QtGui.QGroupBox

sticky_mode¶
mfm.fluorescence.fps.dynamic.simulate_trajectory(d, ds, dg, t_max, t_step, diffusion_coefficient, slow_fact)[source]¶

d density of whole av in shape ng, ng, ng (as generated by fps library) ds density_slow of slow av (has to be same shape as fast av only different occupancy) dimensions = 2; % two dimensional simulation tau = .1; % time interval in seconds time = tau * 1:N; % create a time vector for plotting

k = sqrt(D * dimensions * tau);

http://labs.physics.berkeley.edu/mediawiki/index.php/Simulating_Brownian_Motion

mfm.fluorescence.fps.functions module¶

mfm.fluorescence.fps.functions.RDAMean(av1, av2, **kwargs)[source]¶

Calculate the mean distance between two accessible volumes

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'
>>> structure = mfm.structure.Structure(pdb_filename)
>>> av1 = mfm.fluorescence.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=72, atom_name='CB')
>>> av2 = mfm.fluorescence.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=134, atom_name='CB')
>>> mfm.fluorescence.fps.functions.RDAMean(av1, av2)
52.93390285282142
mfm.fluorescence.fps.functions.RDAMeanE(av1, av2, R0=52.0, **kwargs)[source]¶

Calculate the FRET-averaged (PDA/Intensity) distance between two accessible volumes

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'
>>> structure = mfm.Structure(pdb_filename)
>>> av1 = mfm.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=72, atom_name='CB')
>>> av2 = mfm.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=134, atom_name='CB')
>>> mfm.fps.RDAMeanE(av1, av2)
52.602731299544686
mfm.fluorescence.fps.functions.dRmp(av1, av2)[source]¶

Calculate the distance between the mean position of two accessible volumes

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'
>>> structure = mfm.Structure(pdb_filename)
>>> av1 = mfm.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=72, atom_name='CB')
>>> av2 = mfm.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=134, atom_name='CB')
>>> mfm.fps.dRmp(av1, av2)
49.724995634807691

mfm.fluorescence.fps.functions.make_subav(density, dg, radius, rs, r0)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • density – numpy-array density of the accessible volume dimension ng, ng, ng uint8 numpy array as obtained of fps
  • ng – int number of grid points
  • dg – float grid resolution of the density grid
  • radius – float radius around the list of points. all points within a radius of r0 around the points in rs are part of the subav. each slow point is assiciated to one slow-radius
  • rs – list list of points (x,y,z) defining the subav
  • r0 – is the position of the accessible volume

Examples

>>> import mfm
>>> import numpy as np
>>> av = np.
>>> av =
>>> mfm.fluorescence.fps.subav()
mfm.fluorescence.fps.functions.modify_av(density, dg, radius, rs, r0, factor)[source]¶

Multiplies density by factor if within radius

Parameters:
  • density – numpy-array density of the accessible volume dimension ng, ng, ng uint8 numpy array as obtained of fps
  • dg – float grid resolution of the density grid
  • radius – numpy-array/list radius around the list of points. all points within a radius of r0 around the points in rs are part of the subav. each slow point is associated to one slow-radius
  • rs – numpy-array/list list of points (x,y,z) defining the subav
  • r0 – numpy-array is the position of the accessible volume
  • factor – float factor by which density is multiplied
mfm.fluorescence.fps.functions.random_distances(av1, av2, **kwargs)[source]¶

@nb.jit def random_distances(av1, av2, nSamples):

p1 = av1.points p2 = av2.points

lp1 = p1.shape[0] lp2 = p2.shape[0]

distances = np.empty(nSamples, dtype=np.float64)

for i in range(nSamples):

i1 = random.randint(0, lp1) i2 = random.randint(0, lp2) distances[i] = sqrt(

(p1[i1, 0] - p2[i2, 0]) * (p1[i1, 0] - p2[i2, 0]) + (p1[i1, 1] - p2[i2, 1]) * (p1[i1, 1] - p2[i2, 1]) + (p1[i1, 2] - p2[i2, 2]) * (p1[i1, 2] - p2[i2, 2])

)

return distances

mfm.fluorescence.fps.functions.reset_density_av(density)[source]¶

Sets all densities in av to 1.0 if the density is bigger than 0.0

Parameters:density – numpy-array
Returns:
mfm.fluorescence.fps.functions.widthRDA(av1, av2, **kwargs)[source]¶

Calculate the width of the distance distribution between two accessible volumes

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'
>>> structure = mfm.structure.Structure(pdb_filename)
>>> av1 = mfm.fluorescence.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=72, atom_name='CB')
>>> av2 = mfm.fluorescence.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=134, atom_name='CB')
>>> mfm.fluorescence.fps.functions.widthRDA(av1, av2)
52.93390285282142

mfm.fluorescence.fps.static module¶

mfm.fluorescence.fps.static.calculate_1_radius(l, w, r, atom_i, x, y, z, vdw, **kwargs)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • l – float linker length
  • w – float linker width
  • r – float dye-radius
  • atom_i – int attachment-atom index
  • x – array Cartesian coordinates of atoms (x)
  • y – array Cartesian coordinates of atoms (y)
  • z – array Cartesian coordinates of atoms (z)
  • vdw – Van der Waals radii (same length as number of atoms)
  • linkersphere – float Initial linker-sphere to start search of allowed dye positions
  • linknodes – int By default 3
  • vdwRMax – float Maximal Van der Waals radius
  • dg – float Resolution of accessible volume in Angstrom
  • verbose – bool If true informative output is printed on std-out

Examples

Calculating accessible volume using provided pdb-file

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'
>>> residue_number = 18
>>> atom_name = 'CB'
>>> attachment_atom = 1
>>> av = mfm.fps.AV(pdb_filename, attachment_atom=1, verbose=True)

Calculating accessible volume using provided Structure object

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'
>>> structure = mfm.Structure(pdb_filename)
>>> av = mfm.fps.AV(structure, attachment_atom=1, verbose=True)
Calculating accessible volume
-----------------------------
Loading PDB
Calculating initial-AV
Linker-length  : 20.00
Linker-width   : 0.50
Linker-radius  : 5.00
Attachment-atom: 1
AV-resolution  : 0.50
AV: calculate1R
Number of atoms: 2647
Attachment atom: [ 33.28   58.678  40.397]
Points in AV: 111911
Points in total-AV: 111911

Using residue_seq_number and atom_name to calculate accessible volume, this also works without chain_identifier. However, only if a single-chain is present.

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'
>>> structure = mfm.Structure(pdb_filename)
>>> av = mfm.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=11, atom_name='CB', verbose=True)

If save_av is True the calculated accessible volume is save to disk. The filename of the calculated accessible volume is determined by output_file

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'
>>> structure = mfm.Structure(pdb_filename)
>>> av = mfm.fluorescence.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=11, atom_name='CB', verbose=True, save_av=True, output_file='test')
Calculating accessible volume
-----------------------------
Loading PDB
Calculating initial-AV
Linker-length  : 20.00
Linker-width   : 0.50
Linker-radius  : 5.00
Attachment-atom: 174
AV-resolution  : 0.50
AV: calculate1R
Number of atoms: 2647
Attachment atom: [ 41.606  44.953  36.625]
Points in AV: 22212
Points in total-AV: 22212

  • x – array Cartesian coordinates of atoms (x)
  • y – array Cartesian coordinates of atoms (y)
  • z – array Cartesian coordinates of atoms (z)
  • vdw – Van der Waals radii (same length as number of atoms)
  • linkersphere – float Initial linker-sphere to start search of allowed dye positions
  • linknodes – int By default 3
  • vdw_max – float Maximal Van der Waals radius
  • dg – float Resolution of accessible volume in Angstrom
  • verbose – bool If true informative output is printed on std-out
Returns:

class mfm.fluorescence.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=None, atom_name=None, chain_identifier=None, linker_length=20.0, linker_width=0.5, radius1=5.0, radius2=4.5, radius3=3.5, output_file='out', attachment_atom_index=None, simulation_type='AV1', position_name=None, residue_name=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Examples

Calculating accessible volume using provided pdb-file

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'
>>> residue_number = 18
>>> atom_name = 'CB'
>>> attachment_atom = 1
>>> av = mfm.fps.AV(pdb_filename, attachment_atom=1, verbose=True)

Calculating accessible volume using provided Structure object

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'
>>> structure = mfm.Structure(pdb_filename)
>>> av = mfm.fps.AV(structure, attachment_atom=1, verbose=True)
Calculating accessible volume
-----------------------------
Loading PDB
Calculating initial-AV
Linker-length  : 20.00
Linker-width   : 0.50
Linker-radius  : 5.00
Attachment-atom: 1
AV-resolution  : 0.50
AV: calculate1R
Number of atoms: 2647
Attachment atom: [ 33.28   58.678  40.397]
Points in AV: 111911
Points in total-AV: 111911

Using residue_seq_number and atom_name to calculate accessible volume, this also works without chain_identifier. However, only if a single-chain is present.

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'
>>> structure = mfm.Structure(pdb_filename)
>>> av = mfm.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=11, atom_name='CB', verbose=True)

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'

>>> av = mfm.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=11, atom_name='CB', verbose=True, save_av=True, output_file='test')

Rmp¶

The mean position of the accessible volume (average x, y, z coordinate)

atoms¶
calc_slow_av(slow_centers=None, slow_radius=None, save=False, replace_density=False, **kwargs)[source]¶

Calculates a subav given the accessible volume determined during class initiation.

Parameters:
  • slow_centers – array_like A list of Cartesian coordinated representing the slow centers. The shape should be (n,3) where n is the number of slow centers.
  • slow_radius – array_like, or float A list of radii the shape
  • save – bool If save is True the slow-accessible volume is saved to an xyz-file with the suffix ‘_slow’
  • verbose – bool
  • replace_density – bool If replace_density is True the AV-density will be replaced by the density of the slow accessible volume
Returns:

Examples

Using residue_seq_number and atom_name to calculate accessible volume, this also works without chain_identifier. However, only if a single-chain is present.

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'
>>> structure = mfm.Structure(pdb_filename)
>>> av = mfm.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=11, atom_name='CB', verbose=True)

Now lets determine the points within the AV within a certain radius

>>> av.calc_slow_av(slow_centers=np.array([[10, 5.0, 2.1]]), slow_radius=5.0, verbose=True)
Calculating slow-AV:
[[ 10.    5.    2.1]]
Calculating slow AV
slow centers:
[[ 10.    5.    2.1]]
Points in slow-AV: 0

There are no points within a radius of 5.0. At a bigger radius will find some points.

>>> av.calc_slow_av(slow_centers=np.array([[10, 5.0, 2.1]]), slow_radius=70.0, verbose=True)
Calculating slow-AV:
[[ 10.    5.    2.1]]
Calculating slow AV
slow centers:
[[ 10.    5.    2.1]]
Points in slow-AV: 2809

Parameters:av –
Returns:

Examples

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_filename = '/sample_data/structure/T4L_Topology.pdb'
>>> structure = mfm.Structure(pdb_filename)
>>> av1 = mfm.fluorescence.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=72, atom_name='CB')
>>> av2 = mfm.fluorescence.fps.AV(structure, residue_seq_number=134, atom_name='CB')
>>> av1.dRDA(av2)

get_random_distance(av, **kwargs)[source]¶

pRDA(av, **kwargs)[source]¶

Calculates the distance distribution with respect to a second accessible volume and returns the distance axis and the probability of the respective distance. By default the distance-axis “mfm.rda_axis” is taken to generate the histogram.

Parameters:
  • av – Accessible volume
  • kwargs –
Returns:
save(filename, mode='xyz')[source]¶

Saves the accessible volume as xyz-file

widthRDA(av)[source]¶
class mfm.fluorescence.fps.AvPotential(distances=None, positions=None, av_samples=10000, min_av=150, verbose=False)[source]¶

Bases: object

The AvPotential class provides the possibility to calculate the reduced or unreduced chi2 given a set of labeling positions and experimental distances. Here the labeling positions and distances are provided as dictionaries.

Examples

>>> import json
>>> labeling_file = './sample_data/model/labeling.json'
>>> labeling = json.load(open(labeling_file, 'r'))
>>> distances = labeling['Distances']
>>> positions = labeling['Positions']
>>> import mfm
>>> av_potential = mfm.fps.AvPotential(distances=distances, positions=positions)
>>> structure = mfm.Structure('/sample_data/model/HM_1FN5_Naming.pdb')
>>> av_potential.getChi2(structure)
calc_avs()[source]¶

Calculates/recalculates the accessible volumes.

calc_distances(structure=None, verbose=False)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • structure – Structure If this object is provided the attributes regarding dye-attachment are kept constant and the structure is changed prior calculation of the distances.
  • verbose – bool If this is True output to stdout is generated
chi2¶

The current unreduced chi2 (recalculated at each call)

getChi2(structure=None, reduced=False, verbose=False)[source]¶
Parameters:
  • structure – Structure A Structure object if provided the attributes regarding dye-attachment are kept constant and the structure is changed prior calculation of the distances.
  • reduced – bool If True the reduced chi2 is calculated (by default False)
  • verbose – bool Output to stdout
Returns:

A float containig the chi2 (reduced or unreduced) of the current or provided structure.
